title: ETZ Swap and MoneroDEX Partnership: A Simpler Way to Compare Swap Routes Without Giving Up Control

friendlyUrls.anchor: listed in a top no‑KYC catalog

keyQuestions: What is MoneroDEX and what does it actually do when comparing swap routes?
Does MoneroDEX custody funds or require deposits before you choose a provider?
Why would a user pick ETZ Swap from the offers list — what’s the practical difference?
What should you compare: provider rate, provider fee, network fees, or execution time?
What information is safe to share with support if something feels off during a swap?
How do you reduce wrong-network / wrong-address mistakes in a compare → choose → execute flow?
quickSteps: Compare offers calmly: pick based on your real constraint (speed, simplicity, terms), not only the headline rate.
Verify the basics twice: asset, network, deposit address, and destination address.
Execute from a clean environment: avoid rushing on a compromised or overloaded device.
If support is needed, share only public data: TXID, time sent, amount, and asset/network used.
Keep control boundaries strict: never share recovery secrets and never accept “remote help.”
riskNotes: Aggregators reduce tab-hopping, but look‑alike domains and fake “route” pages still exist — verify URLs letter‑for‑letter.
A slightly better quote can be offset by network fees or a slower route; compare time and conditions, not just price.
Multi‑network assets make mistakes easy; the TXID’s chain must match the chain you intended to use.
Scammers target urgency windows with fake support and “instant fixes”; share only public info and never seeds/keys.
